pred_note: In this dialogue, the patient (Charles) and the doctor discuss Charles' breathing difficulties. Charles mentions that he has been experiencing shortness of breath and catches his breath more often than before. The doctor asks about other symptoms and Charles mentions that his eyes water and he sometimes gets eyebugers, similar to his dog. The doctor suggests that it could be allergies and asks if Charles has noticed any rashes, nausea, or vomiting. Charles mentions that he has diarrhea after heavy drinking but no other symptoms. The doctor asks about any history of allergies and Charles says there is none. Charles mentions that he experiences symptoms in all three situations - at home, around the cat, and outside the house. The doctor performs a physical exam and finds faint expiratory wheezing in Charles' lung fields. The doctor reviews Charles' chest x-ray and pulmonary function test, both of which were normal. The doctor diagnoses Charles with newly diagnosed allergic asthma and prescribes an albuterol inhaler and Singulair to manage the asthma. The doctor also plans to proceed with allergy testing to identify potential triggers for Charles' symptoms. Charles asks if he should bring his cats to the appointment, and the doctor confirms that he should. The doctor schedules a follow-up appointment for next week to schedule the skin testing.

Patient: The patient was raking leaves in their yard and shortly after, their back started tightening up and they experienced pins and needles in their right foot. They had a similar back pain episode three years ago but it resolved after a day. The patient tried icing and taking two Advils, but it provided no relief. The pain is worse when bending over and improves when sitting or after a hot shower. The patient does not engage in regular physical activity.

Doctor: The doctor examined the patient's lower back and found pain upon palpation around the L5. The patient's partner reported that the pain is worse when standing up. The patient also experienced pain when the doctor pushed on their back. The patient mentioned tingling in their right leg. An X-ray was taken, which showed no abnormalities. The doctor diagnosed the patient with a sprained low back and prescribed rest, meloxicam, and physical therapy. If the symptoms do not improve after two weeks, an MRI may be considered.

Patient's Partner: The patient's partner expressed concern about the patient's pain and high pain tolerance. They thought the pain was more significant this time compared to a similar incident last week.

Doctor: The doctor acknowledged the partner's concern and decided to monitor the patient's condition for two weeks before considering an MRI. The doctor also mentioned that the patient recently had surgery.

Medical information: Patient experienced sudden back pain and pins and needles in right foot after raking leaves. History of previous back pain episode. Pain worsened with bending over, improved when sitting or after hot shower. Pain upon palpation around L5. Tingling sensation in right leg. X-ray showed no abnormalities. Diagnosis: sprained low back. Treatment: rest, meloxicam medication, physical therapy. MRI may be considered if symptoms do not improve after two weeks. The patient's partner expressed concern and suggested an immediate MRI, but the doctor advised monitoring for two weeks first.

The patient, Gregory, has had a nonhealing foot ulcer for two months. The ulcer has recently become red and is draining. The patient believes they may have gotten the ulcer from walking barefoot on the beach. They have not picked up antibiotics prescribed by their primary care physician (PCP) yet. The patient has diabetes, but their blood sugar is not regularly checked and their last A1C was around 10, indicating poor control. The doctor examines the foot and finds a circular wound with redness, drainage, and edema. There is no bone infection present, based on an x-ray. The doctor plans to order an ankle brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply and perform a debridement to remove dead tissue. The patient will be prescribed clindamycin for the infection and will be given a surgical shoe to relieve pressure on the foot. They will return in two weeks for a follow-up. The doctor advises the patient to call the office if any issues arise between appointments, and to seek urgent care or the ER for emergencies.

Patient's name: Stephanie Morales
Age: 36
Gender: Female
Medical history: Diabetes and high blood pressure

Chief complaint: Ankle pain

Presenting complaint: Two days ago, slipped on ice and twisted left ankle

Symptoms: Soreness, swelling, difficulty walking

Treatment tried: Ibuprofen, ice, elevation (provides some relief)

Additional medical information:
- History of diabetes: Controlled with metformin, stable blood sugar levels, regular monitoring of blood sugars
- Due for an eye exam for diabetes checkup
- History of high blood pressure: Taking norvasc, blood pressure stable (120/70), refill needed
- Hemoglobin A1c last recorded as 6.8

Doctor's findings:
- Neck, lung, and heart exams normal
- Systolic ejection murmur (unchanged from previous exam)
- Normal belly exam
- Ankle exam: tenderness over lateral malleolus and fifth metatarsal, pain with valgus stressing

Diagnosis: Ankle sprain, possibility of fracture

Treatment plan:
- Order an x-ray to rule out fracture
- Place patient in an air splint and provide crutches
- Prescribe naprosyn 500mg twice a day for pain control
- Instruct patient to avoid weightbearing and keep ankle elevated, use ice
- If x-ray shows a fracture, refer patient to orthopedics; if no fracture, adjust treatment accordingly

Additional plan:
- Diabetes management: Keep eye appointment, continue metformin
- Order another hemoglobin A1c, baseline labs
- Refill norvasc
- Continue monitoring blood pressure, report any changes

Follow-up: Patient to call if any issues or to schedule an appointment sooner

Note: Patient expresses desire to get back to exercising.

The patient visited the doctor because they have a non-healing wound on their right foot. The wound has been present for about two to three weeks and started as a blister after wearing new shoes. The patient has already finished a course of antibiotics prescribed by their primary care physician, but the wound has not improved. They are unable to feel any pain in the foot due to neuropathy. The patient has not experienced any other symptoms such as fever, chills, or drainage from the wound. The doctor conducted a physical exam and noted a circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, with yellow slough and minimal granulation tissue. There is no surrounding redness or cellulitis. The doctor performed an ankle brachial index (ABI) test to evaluate the blood supply to the foot and will perform debridement to remove dead tissue. The doctor will prescribe collagenase ointment and instruct the patient to wear a surgical shoe to relieve pressure on the wound. The doctor does not believe additional antibiotics are necessary but may refer the patient to a vascular specialist if the ABI indicates poor blood supply. The doctor also mentioned the importance of getting the patient's diabetes under control to facilitate wound healing, suggesting a potential diabetic consult to discuss dietary modifications. The patient did not have any further questions.

In this patient-doctor dialogue, William explains to the doctor that he injured his right knee while at a trampoline park. He heard a snap and immediately felt pain when he landed on the trampoline. The doctor asks about William's regular exercise routine and determines that he does not have one, and the trampoline park visit was just for fun. William experienced pain on the outside of his right knee and heard a popping sound when he landed. He has been taking Tylenol for the pain, but it hasn't been effective. He has not tried any other methods of pain relief. The injury occurred a week prior to the doctor's appointment. The doctor also discusses other health issues with William, including hypertension, diabetes, and diet. The doctor notes that William's blood pressure is high and may need to adjust his medication. He also recommends checking blood sugar levels more frequently and potentially adjusting diabetes medication. The doctor performs a physical exam and notices some bruising and swelling on the lateral aspect of William's knee. An x-ray shows no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality. The doctor diagnoses William with a lateral ligament strain and prescribes meloxicam for pain and swelling. Physical therapy is recommended to strengthen the muscles around the knee. The doctor plans to continue monitoring William's hypertension, ordering an echo to assess his heart, and orders an A1c and lipid panel to evaluate his diabetes management.

The patient, Matthew, has been experiencing back pain for a long time, which worsens when sitting or standing. He also experiences pain radiating down his left leg. The pain is described as an electric toothache and rates it as 6/10 currently, but can reach 13/10 at its worst. The pain is alleviated when lying down. The doctor examines Matthew and finds tenderness at the L4 vertebrae, pain with flexion and extension of the back, and weakness in the legs. The MRI results show a herniated disc at the L4-L5 level, causing nerve root impingement. The doctor recommends an epidural steroid injection to alleviate the pain and refers Matthew to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. Follow-up appointments are scheduled for a month later. Matthew agrees to the treatment plan and prepares for the injection.

The patient, Jacqueline, is anxious about her recent blood work which indicates that she has hepatitis C. She has never been told about this before and denies any history of IV drug use or known hepatitis C positive partners. She used to use IV drugs and drink heavily in the past but has been clean for over fifteen years. Currently, she drinks about one beer a day and smokes one to two cigarettes a day. She also mentions feeling tired at the end of the day. She has a family history of hypertension, diabetes, and depression. The doctor performs a physical exam and finds no significant abnormalities except for a 2/6 systolic murmur on heart exam. The doctor informs Jacqueline that her HCV antibody test was positive and her liver panel showed an elevated AST but other liver enzymes were within normal limits. The doctor plans to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of liver disease through additional blood work and an ultrasound. Jacqueline asks if her wife and children should be tested as well, and the doctor recommends starting with the same screening for them. The appointment ends with the nurse scheduling future appointments and Jacqueline will follow up with the doctor in three weeks.

The patient, Julie, is seeing the doctor about her frequent and severe headaches. Julie has been struggling with headaches for years, initially associated with her menstrual cycle and stress. However, recently her headaches have been more frequent and severe. The headaches are mostly on the right side, behind her eye, and have a pulsating sensation. Julie has noticed that exercise, specifically jogging, triggers worse headaches. She has also been experiencing ringing in her ears and occasional blurred vision on the side of her vision. Julie does not have any numbness or tingling in her hands, feet, or face. 

During the physical examination, the doctor finds papilledema, swelling behind the eye, and conducts a neurological exam with normal results. The doctor suspects idiopathic intracranial hypertension, characterized by increased pressure in the brain without a known cause. Further tests, such as an MRI to check for other conditions and a spinal tap to evaluate and potentially decrease the pressure, are recommended. The doctor also suggests a complete eye exam by a neuro-ophthalmologist. Medications can be used to decrease the pressure in the brain and alleviate symptoms, and lifestyle changes, including exercise and weight loss, are important for treatment.

The doctor will work on getting insurance preapproval for the MRI and schedule the necessary tests and appointments. No surgery is mentioned as an immediate requirement.

The patient, Jack, presents to the doctor with neck pain following a car accident. The accident occurred a week ago and the pain is rated as a seven on a scale of one to ten. The pain is experienced when moving the head and is located in the back of the neck. Ibuprofen provided minimal relief. The patient has had some headaches but no other symptoms such as hearing or visual disturbances. There is no swelling or bruising on the neck. During the physical examination, pressing on the side of the neck and flexion and extension of the neck caused pain. There is also pain with rotation and lateral bending. X-ray results showed no fractures or bony abnormalities. The doctor diagnoses the patient with neck strain or whiplash. Treatment involves anti-inflammatories (Motrin), a muscle relaxant (Flexeril), and conservative neck movement. An MRI is ordered to rule out a concussion and assess for nerve impingement. Referral to physical rehab or a chiropractor is considered. The patient expresses concerns about chiropractic treatment, but other options are discussed. The patient has no further questions.

The patient, named Bobby, visits the doctor with complaints of persistent shoulder pain on his right side. He attributes the pain to previous injuries from playing baseball and recent work in his backyard. The pain is located on the outside of his shoulder and is more noticeable when he raises his arm. He experiences pain only when he moves his arm and also at night due to sleeping on that side. The patient has been taking Advil and icing the area for relief. The doctor evaluates the patient's vital signs and performs a physical exam, finding limited range of motion and tenderness at the great tuberosity of the humerus. X-ray results show no fractures. The doctor diagnoses rotator cuff tendinopathy and prescribes an MRI to rule out any other issues. The patient is referred to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks, and if symptoms do not improve, a steroid injection is considered. The doctor also addresses the patient's foot soreness and recommends soaking in Epsom salts for relief. The patient agrees with the plan and expresses hope for improvement.

The patient, Mr. Jackson, is a 45-year-old male with a history of type two diabetes and mild intermittent asthma. He presents to the doctor with right elbow pain, which he attributes to playing tennis. The pain is located on the outside of the elbow and is described as sharp, stabbing, and very painful when in use. The doctor asks about any trauma or worsening factors, as well as other symptoms, such as pain radiating down the arm or shoulder, but the patient reports none. He has tried over-the-counter pain medications and ice, but they provide only temporary relief.

The doctor discusses the patient's medical history, including his diabetes, asthma, allergies, and past surgical procedures. The patient's heart exam reveals a grade three out of six systolic ejection murmur, which has not changed since the last exam. The musculoskeletal exam reveals tenderness and pain in the right elbow, both with passive range of motion and resisted extension of the wrist. The x-ray shows no fractures or other abnormalities. The patient denies having a fever.

The doctor's assessment is acute lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, due to overuse. The doctor recommends rest, avoiding repetitive stress, and stopping tennis for four to six weeks. The patient is advised to ice the elbow and is given a brace. A prescription for Ultram (tramadol) is given for pain relief. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in four weeks.

Regarding the patient's diabetes, the doctor notes that blood sugar levels have been elevated, likely due to increased candy consumption during Easter. The doctor recommends increasing the dosage of metformin to one thousand milligrams twice a day and asks the patient to monitor blood sugar levels twice daily for the next two weeks. Hemoglobin A1c and CBC blood tests are ordered. The doctor also orders a Chem-12 blood test. 

The patient's mild intermittent asthma remains under control with the current medication regimen, but a refill for the albuterol prescription is given.

Overall, the patient's conditions are addressed with specific recommendations and medication adjustments. The doctor plans to reevaluate the elbow in four weeks and make further decisions based on the patient's progress.

- The patient, Angela, is experiencing kidney stone pain, but believes the stone has passed.
- She has a history of hypertension and diabetes.
- The doctor suggests a referral to a urologist for further evaluation of the recurring kidney stones.
- The doctor notes that Angela's blood pressure is slightly elevated and suggests monitoring it outside of the clinic to rule out white coat syndrome.
- The doctor advises Angela to improve her diet, limiting sodium intake, and potentially seeking the help of a dietitian.
- Angela is taking her prescribed metformin for diabetes, but does not check her blood sugar levels regularly.
- The doctor recommends blood sugar monitoring before each meal to determine appropriate food intake.
- The doctor performs a physical exam and suggests a urinalysis and urine culture to ensure the kidney stone has passed.
- Angela requests a referral to see a specific urologist, Dr. Harris.
- The doctor plans to continue Angela's current hypertension medication and prescribes a consult with a nutritionist.
- Angela is encouraged to practice good sleep hygiene and is given the option to take melatonin as needed for insomnia.
- A follow-up appointment is scheduled in three months.

The patient, Betty, is experiencing frequent asthma symptoms including coughing and wheezing. She has noticed that her symptoms are triggered by getting sick with a cold and being around her aunt's cat. She has been having breathing problems almost every month for the past six months and has had to visit urgent care and the emergency department multiple times. She currently uses a blue inhaler called ventolin for relief, needing to use it almost every day and sometimes waking up at night to use it as well. She has never been hospitalized for asthma except when she was eight years old. During her urgent care and ER visits, she has been prescribed prednisone multiple times. Betty does not smoke or use any tobacco or vaping products. She is occasionally exposed to secondhand smoke in bars, which irritates her symptoms. The doctor performs a physical exam and listens to Betty's heart and lungs, finding diminished lung sounds with occasional wheezing. The doctor diagnoses Betty with moderate intermittent asthma based on her symptoms and the results of her pulmonary function test. The doctor prescribes Flovent inhaler twice a day as an inhaled steroid to reduce daily symptoms and the need for the rescue inhaler. The doctor also plans to create an asthma action plan for Betty and schedules a follow-up appointment in one month.

The patient, Larry, has been experiencing back pain for a couple of years and has tried various treatments without success. He recalls the pain starting after moving furniture. The pain is sharp and stabbing and radiates down to his right leg and big toe. He also experiences numbness and tingling in his leg and foot. Larry does not have any loss of sensation or weakness in his genital or rectal area, and does not have any loss of bladder or bowel control. He has tried physical therapy and pain medications, but they were only temporary solutions. Surgery was mentioned as an option, but Larry wants to avoid it. He has gained weight due to decreased activity. Larry used to play golf, but his back pain has hindered his progress. There is no family history of spine conditions and he quit smoking twenty years ago. The doctor performs a physical exam and finds tenderness and positive straight leg test on the right side. A review of the MRI shows a herniated disc at the L4-L5 level with nerve impingement, causing radiculopathy. The doctor recommends a spinal injection with corticosteroid to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. The procedure should be done under fluoroscopy to accurately target the affected area. The doctor explains that Larry may need multiple injections, but generally not more than four times a year. Larry agrees to start the injections, understanding that it is a relatively quick and common procedure.

The patient, who recently experienced knee pain after a skiing accident on their boat, visits the doctor. The doctor asks about the details of the accident and the patient's symptoms. The patient reports no popping sensation, only a stretching feeling and subsequent swelling. They were able to get out of the water by themselves, but movement like squatting and bending is painful. This is the first time the patient injured their knee. The doctor also discusses the patient's high blood pressure and confirms they are taking their medication without any issues. The doctor asks about any foot numbness or tingling, to which the patient responds with only swelling and pain in the knee. The patient has been taking over-the-counter Aleve and using cold packs for pain relief. The doctor notes that the patient had tonsil surgery in the past and proceeds with a physical examination. The findings include good blood pressure management, no abnormalities in the neck and heart exams, clear lungs, swelling and pain in the right knee, decreased range of motion, and some inflammation. The doctor suspects a medial collateral ligament strain and plans to order an x-ray to rule out any broken bones. They will refer the patient to physical therapy for muscle strengthening. The doctor will also prescribe meloxicam for swelling and pain. The patient asks if they can still ski with the medication, but the doctor advises them to rest and avoid skiing until further evaluation. Regarding hypertension, the doctor will continue the current medication, order a lipid panel test, and administer a tetanus shot as needed. The patient agrees with the treatment plan and thanks the doctor.

The patient, Kyle, initially went to see his primary care physician (PCP) for a cough, which was diagnosed as bronchitis. However, a chest x-ray revealed a lung nodule, which was confirmed by a CT scan. Kyle was then referred to the doctor he is currently seeing for further evaluation. Kyle expresses his nervousness about the situation.

The doctor assures Kyle that they will work together as a team and offers support to alleviate his nervousness. They discuss the duration of Kyle's cough, which started about three months ago after he loaded hay while taking care of his horses. Kyle mentions that he exercises frequently, especially biking, and rarely gets sick. The cough has since gone away.

The doctor shares their own love for biking and the new trails in the area. They promise to help Kyle and even suggest going for a bike ride together. The doctor then asks about Kyle's rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and how he manages it. Kyle mentions taking methotrexate and staying active, with occasional problems in his hands but no recent flares.

The doctor notes that Kyle had previously smoked but has quit seven years ago, which is good for his health. They inquire about any pain or shortness of breath, to which Kyle responds negatively. The doctor asks about family history, specifically any lung cancer or other malignancies, to which Kyle mentions his mother's breast cancer but states that she is doing well.

The doctor proceeds with a physical examination, finding no abnormalities except for minor swelling in Kyle's knuckles due to his RA. The doctor reviews the results of the chest CT, which showed a two-centimeter nodule in the right upper lobe of Kyle's lung. They note its smooth appearance and the absence of emphysematous disease.

Based on their assessment, the doctor recommends conducting pulmonary function tests (PFT) to establish a baseline for lung function and schedules a PET-CT scan to determine the metabolic activity of the nodule, which can indicate if it's cancerous or inflammatory. The doctor proposes removing the nodule through video-assisted thoracoscopy, which would involve three small incisions on the side of Kyle's right chest. They will use a camera and scope to remove the nodule and a small portion of the lung under general anesthesia. Kyle would stay in the hospital for one night and have a chest tube until the following day.

Regarding his RA, the doctor advises Kyle to continue following up with his rheumatologist and adhering to his medication therapy. The doctor asks if Kyle has any questions or concerns, to which Kyle expresses his fear but acknowledges that he will be okay. The doctor reassures him and goes to get the necessary paperwork to proceed with treatment.

The patient, a 56-year-old male named Tyler, presents with difficulty swallowing. He has a past medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure. He mentions that for the past four to five weeks, it feels like something is always stuck in his throat. He experiences slight pain and occasionally needs help pushing solids down when eating. There is no coughing or other symptoms with swallowing. He has not noticed any blood in stools or vomit, no weight loss, chest pain, or shortness of breath. The doctor suggests sending Tyler to a specialist for further evaluation. They discuss Tyler's diabetes management, which includes taking metformin and checking blood sugar levels. Tyler reports improvements in his diet and exercise and his blood sugar numbers are within the target range. The doctor plans to repeat Tyler's hemoglobin A1c test and check his kidney function. They also note that Tyler has not had an eye referral and will provide one for ophthalmology. Medication refills are discussed, and the doctor will send a refill for Norvasc to the pharmacy. Tyler is scheduled to return in about a month.

Jerry, a 45-year-old male, visited the doctor with an ankle injury. He explains that he hurt his ankle while playing basketball with his son. The ankle is bruised and swollen, and Jerry is experiencing difficulty walking and instability. He mentions that he recently got back into working out and does not want to disrupt his routine. The doctor examines Jerry's ankle and finds exquisite tenderness on the lateral side and some tenderness over the medial deltoid region. An x-ray reveals a displaced lateral malleolus fracture, which is causing the instability. The doctor recommends surgery to repair the fracture and informs Jerry that he will need to rest for about three months. However, he can still coach starting in April. The doctor prescribes meloxicam for swelling and advises Jerry to ice the ankle and elevate it regularly.

This dialogue is between a patient, Mr. Edwards, and Doctor Cruz. Mr. Edwards is a 54-year-old male who is seeking evaluation for facial pain. He describes the pain as stabbing and shooting, primarily located in his right cheekbone area. The pain can become intense and is sometimes triggered by certain temperatures or sensory stimuli. Mr. Edwards does not experience any numbness or tingling in his face, and there is no weakness or changes in vision. He has tried medications like ibuprofen and topical treatments like tiger balm, but they have not provided relief. The episodes of pain can last anywhere from a few minutes to an hour, with a peak severity of 10/10. The doctor performs a physical exam, finding normal motor and sensory functions, except for some numbness and a dull feeling on the right side of the face. Based on the results of an MRI, the doctor suspects trigeminal neuralgia, a condition caused by compression of the trigeminal nerve by a nearby blood vessel. The first line of treatment will be medications like gabapentin or tegretol to reduce the nerve's excitability. If these medications are not effective, surgical options may be considered. The doctor recommends starting with tegretol and informs Mr. Edwards about potential side effects such as memory loss, tingling, imbalance, and dermatological reactions. Genetic testing may be done to ensure safety. They agree to follow up in one month to evaluate the medication's effectiveness and discuss further treatment options if needed.

The patient, Michelle, injured her knee while skiing and had to be taken down the hill by the ski patrol. She is experiencing pain on the outside of her knee and feels like it won't hold her weight. She is unable to fully bend or straighten her knee, and experiences pain when trying to straighten it completely. She does not have any numbness or tingling in her toes and can feel them fine. Michelle leads an active lifestyle, chasing after her two four-year-old children. Her husband helps out, but he is often away for work. The doctor performs a physical exam and finds edema and an effusion over the right knee, as well as decreased flexion and extension. A positive Lachman sign is also observed. The doctor suspects a ruptured ACL and orders a knee MRI to confirm. Michelle is currently taking ibuprofen for pain, which helps somewhat. The doctor prescribes a knee brace for additional support. The next steps will be determined based on the MRI results. Michelle does not have any specific exercise preferences, but hopes to eventually get back to running.

The patient, Brandon, is experiencing neck pain and explains that it is due to multiple car crashes, with the most recent one happening in February. Brandon has previously undergone therapy and surgery for neck pain related to previous car crashes. He rates his pain as a twelve out of ten and mentions that he was prescribed fentanyl for pain relief, but has not received a prescription for several weeks. Brandon also experiences stiffness, sharp incapacitating pain, headaches, dizziness, numbness in the left arm and right leg, and spasms. The doctor performs a physical exam and notes tenderness in the neck area and limited range of movement. The doctor rules out a fracture based on previous imaging results and diagnoses Brandon with a neck sprain. The doctor recommends conservative treatment, such as applying ice, performing exercises, and prescribing robaxin for muscle relaxation. They also discuss the possibility of local injections and referral to pain medication. The doctor advises Brandon to stay off work until the results of an MRI are available.

The patient, Andrew, is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension. He presents with symptoms of an upper respiratory infection, including fatigue, shortness of breath, and possible onset of a cold. Andrew has received both doses of the COVID vaccine and has no history of seasonal allergies. His shortness of breath is primarily experienced while lifting or carrying heavy objects. He reports muscle pain in his elbows and fatigue in his knees, which he attributes to physical exertion. Andrew's other medical conditions, including depression, diabetes, and hypertension, are being managed. He monitors his blood sugar levels regularly and has noticed no significant elevations. He also checks his blood pressure regularly and is taking his prescribed medications. Physical examination reveals scattered ronchi bilaterally on the lung exam, edema in the lower extremities, and tenderness in the elbows upon palpation. Chest x-ray results show no signs of pneumonia or airspace disease. Diabetic labs reveal an elevated hemoglobin A1c of eight. The doctor suspects a viral upper respiratory infection and plans to conduct a COVID test. The doctor suggests taking robitussin for the cough and ibuprofen or Tylenol for fever. Regarding the patient's depression, the doctor suggests considering medication or psychotherapy in the future. The doctor plans to increase Andrew's metformin dosage for his diabetes and orders another hemoglobin A1c test in four months. The patient's high blood pressure is being well-managed with lisinopril, and a lipid panel is ordered. The doctor schedules a follow-up appointment in four months and advises the patient to seek further medical attention if symptoms worsen.

The patient, Andrea, is a 52-year-old female with a medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux. She presents for her annual exam. Andrea reports that she has been doing well, with no joint pain or issues with her medication (methotrexate). However, she has been experiencing palpitations related to her atrial fibrillation, especially when stressed. She has been trying meditation and exercise to relieve stress but with limited success. Her reflux symptoms have improved with medication (protonix) and dietary modifications. Physical examination reveals a slight systolic ejection murmur, clear lungs, and pain in her right elbow. Event monitor results show that Andrea is in and out of atrial fibrillation. Autoimmune panel results indicate well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis. The doctor plans to continue Andrea on methotrexate for her rheumatoid arthritis, refer her to cardiology for a cardiac ablation to maintain normal sinus rhythm, and continue protonix for reflux along with dietary modifications. Andrea will also be provided with a refill for methotrexate.

The doctor and patient discuss the patient's recent emergency room visit. The patient was experiencing elevated blood sugar and feeling woozy. They were not admitted to the hospital but did not monitor their diet closely, resulting in high blood sugar levels. The patient started feeling better after returning home and has since been following their diet. The doctor also discusses the patient's kidney transplant, which is currently stable, and their depression, which is being managed with meditation. The doctor recommends increasing the patient's lantus dosage for hyperglycemia and ordering another hemoglobin a1c test. They also suggest the patient continue their current strategies for managing depression and schedule a follow-up with the doctor managing their kidney transplant medications. Overall, the patient's vital signs and physical exam are normal during the visit.

Jerry is a 54-year-old male with osteoporosis and multiple sclerosis. He presents for an annual exam and mentions experiencing lack of sleep, which has been affecting him. He has tried various strategies for insomnia but nothing seems to help. Jerry does not report any issues with his joints or recent broken bones related to his osteoporosis. He last saw the neurologist six months ago for his multiple sclerosis and is currently taking the medication without any issues. He mentions a lingering issue with his knee surgery causing weakness in his right leg, but otherwise, he feels fine. The doctor does a physical exam and finds that Jerry's vital signs are good, his lungs are clear, and his heart sounds good. Jerry has weakness in his lower extremities, particularly in the right leg, and shows arthritic changes in his right knee. The doctor orders a refill of Fosamax for osteoporosis and advises Jerry to continue seeing the neurologist and taking the medication for multiple sclerosis. The doctor finalizes the note and asks Jerry if he has any questions, to which Jerry replies that he does not.

The patient, Mrs. Martinez, visits Dr. Gomez with complaints of pain in her arm near her wrist. She explains to the doctor that the pain occurred while playing tennis and hitting a backhand shot, causing her arm to jar. The doctor asks if there was any swelling or numbness, to which Mrs. Martinez responds that there was minimal swelling and no numbness. The doctor then inquires about her medical history and she mentions having allergies and taking Flonase. She also mentions a past trauma of falling onto a rake while doing lawn work. The doctor examines her arm and finds tenderness when pressing and bending the arm, especially around the thumb. Based on the examination and x-ray, the doctor concludes that there is no fracture but suspects a strain and contusion in the muscle. The doctor recommends conservative treatment with ice and anti-inflammatory medication (Motrin, 800mg three times a day with food). If the symptoms do not improve within a week, the patient is instructed to follow up. The doctor orders the necessary procedures and medications, and the patient expresses her gratitude.

The patient, Lawrence, is a 62-year-old male with type I diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux. He presents with complaints of shortness of breath and swelling in his legs. He experiences shortness of breath when walking up stairs and has noticed the swelling for about 10 days. He also mentions feeling lethargic and uncomfortable when waking up in the morning. The patient mentions a past occurrence of waking up short of breath at night. The doctor asks about the patient's diabetes and blood sugar levels, as well as his efforts to manage his depression and reflux. Lawrence reports that he has been monitoring his blood sugar levels and has not seen any spikes. He mentions trying natural solutions for his depression but is open to suggestions. The doctor notes that Lawrence has been making lifestyle modifications for his reflux and asks about his alcohol intake and any issues with depression. The patient denies any intention to harm himself or others. The doctor proceeds with a physical exam and finds crackles and 1+ pitting edema in the patient's lungs and lower extremities. The doctor orders a chest x-ray and reviews the results, finding no evidence of airspace disease. The labs also come back normal, ruling out infection. The doctor diagnoses Lawrence with an acute heart failure exacerbation and prescribes Lasix and daily weight monitoring. For his diabetes, the doctor orders a hemoglobin A1c test and recommends follow-up with an endocrinologist and an eye exam. Lawrence is referred to psychiatry for talk therapy to address his depression, and he is advised to continue taking omeprazole for his reflux. Lawrence is instructed to contact the doctor if he experiences any worsening of his breathing.

Ms. James, a 42-year-old female, visits Dr. Cooper for a finger injury sustained while skiing. The injury occurred five days ago and she has been experiencing pain rated at a seven out of ten. She has taken ibuprofen but it did not provide relief. She has not used ice or a splint for the finger. Apart from the finger injury, she has chronic constipation managed with Miralax. She previously had an appendectomy. An x-ray shows no fractures, but the physical examination indicates a sprain of the distal interphalangeal joint of the right index finger. Dr. Cooper recommends a splint and prescribes the anti-inflammatory drug Mobic. Ms. James is instructed to return for a follow-up appointment in two weeks.

Cheryl, a 34-year-old female with a history of hypertension, presents with back pain. She experienced the pain six days ago after walking for an extended period. She has been taking ibuprofen and applying heat but still experiences stiffness. She has been lifting weights three times a week, including deadlifts. The pain is primarily in the lower back on both sides. There is no numbness, tingling, or weakness in her legs. Cheryl's blood pressure has been well controlled with lisinopril. She has nasal congestion due to seasonal allergies. Physical examination reveals tenderness and pain in the lumbar spine, with pain during flexion and extension. Straight leg raise is negative. X-ray and lab results are normal. The diagnosis is lumbar strain, likely due to lifting or exercise. Treatment includes prescribing meloxicam, applying ice or heat, and referral to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. Cheryl should continue taking lisinopril and report any increases in blood pressure readings. She needs a refill of lisinopril, which the doctor orders.

The patient, Mrs. Anderson, presents with left shoulder pain that has lasted for a week. She took Tylenol for a few days, but it didn't help. The pain started after she was in a gymnastics class and may have occurred due to a certain move. The doctor examines her and determines that there is no broken bone or fracture but suspects a joint injury. The doctor suggests using ibuprofen three times a day for a week and recommends using ice or a heat pad if the pain persists. The patient mentions a past surgery on her left arm, but the doctor doesn't believe it is related to the current pain. The doctor advises resting the left arm and not carrying heavy weights, using the right hand instead. If the pain continues after three weeks, the patient should return for further evaluation. The doctor may consider another x-ray at that time. Medications and procedures are ordered as discussed. The patient hopes that ibuprofen will help and asks if she can call the doctor or make another appointment if the pain worsens. The doctor suggests trying Advil or Aleve and thanks the patient.

The patient, Elizabeth, is a 66-year-old female with a history of depression and hypertension. She presents for her annual exam. Elizabeth has been going to therapy once a week and has a good support system at home. Her blood pressure has been normal and she has been taking the prescribed medication for hypertension. During the physical exam, a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and trace lower extremity edema are noted. The EKG results are normal. The doctor determines that Elizabeth is managing her depression well and does not need medication at this time. The plan is to continue the current medication for hypertension, monitor blood pressure, schedule a mammogram, and take all medications at the same time.

Doctor Isabella is seeing a new patient named Jose James, who is experiencing pain in his left shoulder and elbow for the past five months. The pain started after he fell while going up the stairs. Mr. James has been having difficulty lifting weights at the gym and has stopped exercising due to the pain. He and his wife continue to walk daily. He has tried icing but hasn't taken any medication for the pain. There is no numbness or tingling. During the physical examination, the doctor finds tenderness in the left shoulder and elbow and performs several tests which are positive for impingement syndrome of the left shoulder. The doctor recommends starting with physical therapy twice a week and, if that doesn't improve the pain, a cortisone injection can be considered. Mr. James agrees to try physical therapy first and will receive a referral order for therapy. He is advised to continue icing and resting, and to contact the doctor if his symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy.

The doctor spoke with the patient's guest about Randy's symptoms. Randy has had a runny nose and stuffiness since last night. His mucus is currently clear. Randy also has a cough, pulls on his ears, and rubs his nose. He had a rectal temperature of 100.3, indicating a low-grade fever. Randy had a decreased appetite and seemed irritable. His energy level was high, but he had difficulty falling asleep. His older sister and a playmate with a sinus infection have been exposed to him. The guest has been using saline mist, Tylenol, baby Vick's, and a humidifier to alleviate Randy's symptoms. The doctor examined Randy's breathing, ears, and cradle cap. The cradle cap has worsened, and the guest has been using a cradle cap brush and regular Aveeno shampoo. The doctor prescribed medication for a potential barky cough and advised against giving honey. The guest also asked about treating cradle cap. The doctor recommended using regular strength dandruff shampoo twice a week and cautioned about avoiding contact with the eyes. The guest was instructed to monitor Randy's symptoms and return for a follow-up appointment.

Kayla Ward, a 7th grade student, is at the doctor's office for a new visit with her mother regarding her acne, which started two years ago. She has been using Persa-Gel and washing regularly, which has been somewhat helpful. There are no associated symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or pain. Kayla lives with her parents, sister, and pets (a dog, bird, and bunnies). She also participates in sports. Dr. Price asks about the acne on her chest and back, to which Kayla responds that it's not too bad and that she has used over-the-counter washes and Persa-Gel. Kayla's current skincare routine involves wiping her face down in the morning and using the ELF Super Clarity cleanser, toner, and Persa-Gel at night. She sometimes uses the cleanser in the morning if needed. Kayla describes today as a good day for her skin. She does not experience acne flare-ups with her periods and has been getting regular periods for about two years. The biggest flare-up occurred when she started school sports. Mrs. Ward, Kayla's mother, mentions that Kayla has been diligent with her skincare regimen, but it hasn't helped as much as they hoped. Dr. Price performs a full examination and diagnoses Kayla with mild to moderate acne, primarily comodonal with a small inflammatory component. He recommends starting with topical therapy, including washing her face with a mild cleanser in the morning, using a noncomedogenic moisturizer with SPF 30, and applying adapalene, 0.1% cream, in the evening. He advises starting with a few nights a week and gradually increasing to nightly use. If the prescribed medication is expensive or not covered by insurance, over-the-counter alternatives can be tried. Dr. Price also mentions that Kayla has multiple benign moles, which appear normal and do not raise concerns. The next follow-up is scheduled in six months. Kayla agrees to the treatment plan and thanks the doctor. The doctor instructs her to reach out if she has any questions or concerns before the next visit.

Patient: Julia Jones, 25 years old, presenting for evaluation of breast reduction. She has been considering the procedure for about six or seven years. She experiences back pain and neck pain for several years, wears a 34E sports bra, and has bra strap indentations on her shoulders. She does not have any children but may plan to in the future. She experiences occasional numbness, tingling, and nipple pain. She does not have rashes but her breasts are always sweaty. Certain activities such as working out and running are painful. She has been to a chiropractor for her back pain and takes migraine medication.

Doctor: Dr. Gonzalez, a plastic surgeon specializing in breast reduction surgeries. She performs the procedure frequently. She explains the process of breast reduction, which involves removing tissue from the breasts, lifting them, and elevating the nipple position. She discusses the surgery duration, the need for drains, and the clear plastic tape over the incisions to minimize scarring. The doctor mentions that breastfeeding may be affected after the surgery and that the breasts may change in size and appearance over time. She explains the potential for slight alterations in nipple sensation and post-surgery bruising. The doctor mentions that most patients experience relief from back and neck pain after the procedure.

Medical information: Symptomatic macromastia, bilateral breast ptosis, no nipple retraction or discharge, no breast tenderness or masses, no axillary lymphadenopathy. Minimum required resection based on body surface area (BSA) and the Schnur scale is 1792 grams.

Patient: Kelly Wood, born February 15th, 1979. Presented with hematuria and came for a renal ultrasound. Urine dipstick results were negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketones, bilirubin, and glucose. Urine color is yellow and clear, urobilinogen 0.2, pH 5.5, specific gravity 1.020, and there is a trace amount of blood in the urine. Renal ultrasound findings show a 10 cm x 5 cm right kidney with no stones, masses, or hydronephrosis. Left kidney measures 10.8 cm x 5 cm with a non-obstructing 6 mm renal stone. Pre-void urine volume is 533 mL and post-void is 0 mL. 

Doctor: Informs Mrs. Wood about the ultrasound findings, confirming the presence of one non-obstructing kidney stone in the left kidney. Mrs. Wood shares her previous experience of passing two small stones and having episodes of bright red urine and pain while urinating. Pain level at the time was an eight out of ten.

Patient: Reports that pain and discomfort have improved after passing the stones.

Doctor: Notes that Mrs. Wood is currently taking alavert 10 mg and has no drug allergies.

Doctor: Discusses the cause of kidney stones, mentioning factors such as dehydration, family history, certain foods, digestive tract disease, and certain medical conditions.

Patient: Admits to not drinking enough water and consuming sugary drinks like Mountain Dew.

Doctor: Advises Mrs. Wood to drink about half of her body weight in ounces of water per day and avoid sugary drinks. Also recommends reducing sodium intake and limiting consumption of beef, poultry, fish, and pork.

Patient: Asks about specific foods to avoid.

Doctor: Mentions foods rich in sodium oxalate, such as spinach, chocolate, beets, rhubarb, and soy products.

Patient: Expresses willingness to make dietary changes to prevent future kidney stones.

Doctor: Provides a handout with dietary recommendations and instructions on what to avoid.

Patient: Appreciates having information in writing to aid in remembering.

Doctor: Instructs Mrs. Wood to return next year unless she experiences bleeding or pain. Advises her to seek emergency care if she experiences severe pain or bright red blood in her urine.

Doctor: Complete encounter notes with the primary diagnosis of hematuria and secondary diagnosis of chronic urolithiasis. Walks Mrs. Wood to the check-out area.

Patient: Hopes not to experience any further issues and looks forward to seeing the doctor next year.

In this patient-doctor dialogue, the doctor is seeing Melissa Sanchez for a follow-up after her mitral valve repair. The doctor notes that at her previous appointment, she was doing well from a cardiac standpoint and recommended she continue with the same medication. However, an ECG taken on 12/26/2020 reveals atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response and t-wave inversion anteriorly. The patient also has a history of mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, asthma, and recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac workup for coronary artery disease. 

During the appointment, the doctor asks about any new symptoms and the patient reports occasional chest pains and shallow breathing. The symptoms last for a few minutes and then disappear for a couple of weeks. The patient is taking her medications regularly, including coumadin, lasix, and atenolol. She mentions that the atenolol initially made her irritable but she has gotten used to it. 

The doctor performs a physical exam and notes no JVD or abnormal breath sounds in the head and neck and lungs. The patient's heart rhythm is irregularly irregular due to atrial fibrillation. The doctor also checks the patient's belly and extremities, finding no pain or peripheral edema. 

Based on the exam and ECG, the doctor determines that the patient's heart valves are working well and she is recovering nicely from the surgery. The atrial fibrillation is well controlled with medication. The doctor recommends continuing with the current medication regimen and encourages the patient to stay active. 

The doctor schedules a follow-up appointment in about six to nine months, as there are no immediate concerns from a cardiac perspective. The patient thanks the doctor and the appointment concludes.

In this dialogue, the patient, Judy Gomez, visits the doctor for ongoing management of her psoriatic arthritis. The doctor asks about her well-being and mentions the previous discussion about decreasing her prednisone dose. Judy confirms that she is now only taking one prednisone pill and reports that it seems to be enough, although she occasionally takes an extra one when experiencing extra pain in her feet. The doctor notes that they are still on track for discontinuing the prednisone and asks about the effectiveness of methotrexate in relieving joint pain. Judy confirms that it helped, but she had to skip a week of methotrexate due to concerns about its interference with a COVID vaccine. She experienced severe symptoms during that week but resumed taking methotrexate and felt better. The doctor expresses the need to monitor methotrexate due to its high-risk nature and mentions the need for blood work in the future. Judy asks about the bruises she is experiencing, and the doctor attributes them to the prednisone, assuring her that they may disappear once she stops taking it. The doctor then examines Judy's joints and concludes that her treatment is progressing well. They decide to discontinue prednisone, continue with methotrexate, and schedule a follow-up appointment in three months.

Patient information:
- Patient's name: Diana Scott
- Date of birth: 12/8/1920
- Date of service: 7/9/2021
- New patient

Medical information:
- Patient has been diagnosed with a heart murmur.
- The heart murmur is new and described as worrisome.
- No specific symptoms related to the heart murmur are reported.
- Patient experiences severe leg pain.
- Ankle swelling has been present for about 6 months, with fluctuating severity.
- Patient has experienced recent weight loss, currently weighs 120 pounds.
- No fever, chills, or other concerning symptoms reported.
- Patient's son had a heart attack, brother had a stroke, and eldest sister had a heart problem.
- Patient does not smoke and has no known allergies to medications.

Examination findings:
- Blood pressure is good.
- No acute distress observed.
- Systolic murmur heard at the right upper sternal border, with mild radiation to the carotids.
- Gait is normal for age.

Assessment and plan:
- Suspected diagnosis of aortic stenosis based on the presence of a systolic murmur.
- Symptoms may be due to severe aortic stenosis.
- Echocardiogram ordered to assess cardiac structure and function.
- Frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) observed on EKG.
- Further evaluation of PVCs and consideration of ischemic evaluation may be necessary.
- Patient's leg pain and aortic stenosis warrant consideration of transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) procedure.
- Patient will discuss treatment options with primary care provider.
- Statin medication may be discontinued due to leg pain and lack of coronary artery disease history.
- Levothyroxine for hyperthyroidism will continue as prescribed.
- Follow-up appointment scheduled in 3-4 weeks to discuss echocardiogram results and next steps.
